channel.title: ARM Crackme - Starting with EOR
channel.description:
# ARM Crackme - Starting with EOR
@Wunkolo and I have decided that there aren't enough ARM crackmes on the forum and that we should add a few for people that are interested in learning how the architecture works and for those that just want to show their skills :D
We will start very easy with some challenges that don't require any kind of setup or reading up specific processor manuals but that will change when the challenges get harder. A binary is still provided in case static analysis is not your thing, anyways let's start:
## Rules and Goals
In this challenge the goal is to decrypt the password in ever way you want. Post it in spoiler tags under the challenge so we can see who solved it! :D
## Challenge
I've written myself this tool to encrypt all my passwords a few month ago but apparently I forgot to implement a decryption function. I can't find the source either so I'm left with this useless encrypted password. Maybe you can help me decrypt it?
### Encrypted Password
```plain 1D 0E 11 27 0F 6D 11 0C 10 6F 03 6F 6C 0E 21 ``` ### Dump of the relevant assembly
```asm 0845C main STMFD SP!, {R11,LR} 08460 ADD R11, SP, #4 08464 SUB SP, SP, #8 08468 LDR R3, =var_856C ; "%s" 0846C MOV R0, R3 08470 LDR R1, =input 08474 BL __isoc99_scanf 08478 MOV R3, #0 0847C STR R3, [R11,#-8] 08480 B loc_84B8 08484 loc_8484 LDR R2, =var_8570 ; "%02X " 08488 LDR R1, =input 0848C LDR R3, [R11,#-8] 08490 ADD R3, R1, R3 08494 LDRB R3, [R3] 08498 EOR R3, R3, #0x5C 0849C AND R3, R3, #0xFF 084A0 MOV R0, R2 084A4 MOV R1, R3 084A8 BL printf 084AC LDR R3, [R11,#-8] 084B0 ADD R3, R3, #1 084B4 STR R3, [R11,#-8] 084B8 loc_84B8 LDR R3, [R11,#-8] 084BC CMP R3, #0xE 084C0 BLS loc_8484 084C4 LDR R0, =var_8578 ; "" 084C8 BL puts 084CC SUB SP, R11, #4 084D0 LDMFD SP!, {R11,LR} 084D4 BX LR ```
### (Optional) Binary in base64 format
Extract with: ```bash cat base64below.txt | base64 -d | gunzip > binary.elf ```
File type:
```plain ELF 32-bit LSB executable, ARM, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked (uses shared libs), for GNU/Linux 2.6.26, not stripped ```
Base64 encoded gzip archive:
```plain H4sIAErs31oAA5VYb2xUxxGfvT/mABvO2IR/Frk0jmIafD7A5U+qNDbG2KbmT8BtaIXyePaduUvO d6e7d5FpQImxo0atKahFKorS+j6gqGpRRSU+UJVWKa1S1E9ItFL67c7uJUAS1ahKpKYV15mdfe/t 3rWnXlp9+uPmlV0HnvnU65PQ6hGkTUjJaeZXKdtnNZ7G9ZjGR5EuavzXkSyNB8M4MZHNGAXLzFuG ARi6MQrZdhSkCtmxXbuMwpiZGYdc0SqAOZrNW5DLpzLWOAIIrFpOmKkMDAwP7e4ztkZ3OLVuUJH2 ## References
As these challenges are meant for learning this section will contain some resources to look into that will help solving this challenge. [spoiler] https://azeria-labs.com/writing-arm-assembly-part-1/ http://www.davespace.co.uk/arm/introduction-to-arm/ https://static.docs.arm.com/ddi0406/cd/DDI0406C_d_armv7ar_arm.pdf [/spoiler]

item.title: ARM Crackme - Starting with EOR
item.dc:creator: Leeky
item.description:
ARM Crackme - Starting with EOR

@Wunkolo and I have decided that there aren’t enough ARM crackmes on the forum and that we should add a few for people that are interested in learning how the architecture works and for those that just want to show their skills

We will start very easy with some challenges that don’t require any kind of setup or reading up specific processor manuals but that will change when the challenges get harder.
A binary is still provided in case static analysis is not your thing, anyways let’s start:

Rules and Goals

In this challenge the goal is to decrypt the password in ever way you want.
Post it in spoiler tags under the challenge so we can see who solved it!

Challenge

I’ve written myself this tool to encrypt all my passwords a few month ago but apparently I forgot to implement a decryption function.
I can’t find the source either so I’m left with this useless encrypted password. Maybe you can help me decrypt it?

Encrypted Password

1D 0E 11 27 0F 6D 11 0C 10 6F 03 6F  6C 0E 21

Dump of the relevant assembly

0845C main      STMFD   SP!, {R11,LR}
08460           ADD     R11, SP, #4
08464           SUB     SP, SP, #8
08468           LDR     R3, =var_856C  ; "%s"
0846C           MOV     R0, R3
08470           LDR     R1, =input
08474           BL      __isoc99_scanf
08478           MOV     R3, #0
0847C           STR     R3, [R11,#-8]
08480           B       loc_84B8
08484 loc_8484  LDR     R2, =var_8570  ; "%02X "
08488           LDR     R1, =input
0848C           LDR     R3, [R11,#-8]
08490           ADD     R3, R1, R3
08494           LDRB    R3, [R3]
08498           EOR     R3, R3, #0x5C
0849C           AND     R3, R3, #0xFF
084A0           MOV     R0, R2
084A4           MOV     R1, R3
084A8           BL      printf
084AC           LDR     R3, [R11,#-8]
084B0           ADD     R3, R3, #1
084B4           STR     R3, [R11,#-8]
084B8 loc_84B8  LDR     R3, [R11,#-8]
084BC           CMP     R3, #0xE
084C0           BLS     loc_8484
084C4           LDR     R0, =var_8578  ; ""
084C8           BL      puts
084CC           SUB     SP, R11, #4
084D0           LDMFD   SP!, {R11,LR}
084D4           BX      LR

(Optional) Binary in base64 format

Extract with:

cat base64below.txt | base64 -d | gunzip > binary.elf

File type:

ELF 32-bit LSB executable, ARM, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked (uses shared libs), for GNU/Linux 2.6.26, not stripped

Base64 encoded gzip archive:

H4sIAErs31oAA5VYb2xUxxGfvT/mABvO2IR/Frk0jmIafD7A5U+qNDbG2KbmT8BtaIXyePaduUvO
d6e7d5FpQImxo0atKahFKorS+j6gqGpRRSU+UJVWKa1S1E9ItFL67c7uJUAS1ahKpKYV15mdfe/t
vZAPeae53Xnz29mZ2Z3dfftq//BeIQTYjw86gLhL0wDdWLaH6B0EuyECIZQ9Cm0kz50KApx6nQkh
kgKKGoDbdr/GJBUiBZXcTzLku6eYWoAp4EL5eY3pjSBTUL0jOb8Tkjbjix7B/ZIc7YULQSIhaRH5
RWWXbeMg4genmPYAky17rmrF4SGP3b4rnRrtSsc706lMcTJayEa38fuwsn3gwLdULLnNetWuVflO
8vd/YP23+tMfnf5u5clnn1n/7FPFz0o3SbZEYahd0NO/HZeA0u1XpVDYcNL3mE8bg/Arb5062/3g
3rWnXlp9+uPmlV0HnvnU65PQ6hGkTUjJaeZXKdtnNZ7G9ZjGR5EuavzXkSyNB8M4MZHNGAXLzFuG
ARi6MQrZdhSkCtmxXbuMwpiZGYdc0SqAOZrNW5DLpzLWOAIIrFpOmKkMDAwP7e4ztkZ3OLVuUJH2

ezrvPgnwYbjn93c21roqgXJnNVCeq64onyuHFv9Q3UwxePfcfOivs/Ob/329atfbtXqbVm/V6o1a
PUD1K6UFKJcWAuGf/bMpUqoEItgXdFbD78xVA+90VhthrtoYm6veqdU+XES6M4NjhPQRUhu+b4vM
